posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked:
Hello Experts,

Our team is considering purchasing a laser cutter for the upcoming season. After searching, the most recent posts we‚Äôve come across are from before 2020. We‚Äôre looking for:

- A laser cutter with a power of 120+ watts  
- A bed size of 4‚Äô x 4‚Äô  
- Under $7k (something under $5k would be ideal if possible)

Does anyone have a laser cutter they highly recommend?

Thanks in advance!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: A 60-watt machine is sufficient for FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) tasks. However, I would prioritize the overall quality of the machine over its wattage. A wise reminder: "What is cheap, is expensive."

posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked: Yes, cheap products often break or are difficult to use, and I fully understand that. However, I must adhere to the budget guidelines set by my school district. Any item exceeding $5,000 requires three bids. The wattage was recommended by a local engineer.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: The wattage was recommended by a local engineer. Ask him what his opinion on a 60W laser would be, given a workflow mostly involving plywood and delrin (these are, I think, consensus best-materials for FIRST Robotics Competition laser cutting). I think you might get a better quality machine at your price point at that power level. I could be wrong, though!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked: To Be Honest, I'm not sure why they recommended the 100W panel. The main materials we want to use it for are: Plywood - up to 1 inch thick; Polycarb - both 1/8 inch and 1/4 inch thick; Aluminum - engraving.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Extremely important: be prepared for results that may range from acceptable to poor quality, depending on your skills and setup. Use proper ventilation when cutting polycarb, as it produces harmful fumes. A 1/4-inch thickness can be particularly challenging. Delrin is a good alternative because it tends to vaporize rather than melt during cutting, making it less likely to create messy residues. Acrylic offers the best finish but lacks durability, making it suitable mainly for cosmetic purposes. Always opt for low-speed cutting and multiple passes to achieve cleaner results.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked:
You have no idea how much I appreciate the advice! I‚Äôm not an engineering expert, just someone who‚Äôs learned more about engineering over the years through my involvement with FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) for almost two decades.  

Anything else you‚Äôd recommend we watch out for? We‚Äôre planning to use a laser cutter for quick prototyping with plywood and bumper frames. Polycarb is mostly used for protecting components and occasionally for structural pieces. This year, we made our coral intake using both 1/8 and 1/4 polycarb, while last year‚Äôs builds used polycarb side plates on the under the bumper and over the frame. I thought the laser cutter might be a better option for those cuts, freeing up the CNC machine for aluminum work.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Extremely Important: Be prepared to service the thing and replace the lenses/mirrors on a scheduled basis. Really lean into the fact that part turnover on a laser is lightning fast, and use it to iterate rapidly. You don‚Äôt need to waste time on a mill/router until you know the dimensions once you have a laser‚Äîso, don‚Äôt. Lasers are a really good ‚Äúfirst CNC machine‚Äù experience for students because there‚Äôs no workholding and it‚Äôs relatively hard to make the machine damage itself. Make use of that in your training sequence. Let your students have fun making art on the laser when it‚Äôs not in use for other things. Engraving is cool, and is a good low-stakes way to practice fine-tuning the machine settings.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
There are several laser options available. I have owned two, including a CO2 and a 30W fiber model. I haven‚Äôt had much success with engraving aluminum; marking it with spray paint works better.  

A word of advice: If you keep your laser very close to 100% power, its lifespan will decrease significantly. Typically, it lasts about half as long under such conditions. This is especially true if you use it frequently at full power.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Now, this is IF you spend a lot of time at 100%. Addendum: do not. As I mentioned above, the best strategy for both cut quality and tool longevity is to run at lower duty cycles for multiple passes. This takes longer, but the laser is already such a fast machine that the difference doesn‚Äôt matter much. Shoutout to the University of Maryland for teaching me these best practices as a research intern üòä

This innovative combination enables advanced cutting and etching capabilities.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: When considering purchasing a laser for your robotic projects, it's crucial to incorporate SRPP (Self-Reinforced Polypropylene) into your workflow for producing robust and durable robot parts. Products like REV Robotics' MAXComposite sheets and WestCoast Products' SRPP sheets are excellent choices due to their strength and impact resistance, making them ideal for applications such as intakes and bumpers. Both options offer competitive pricing, with REV starting at USD 150 and WestCoast slightly cheaper at USD 149.99. REV also provides detailed machining guidelines for their MAXComposite material, which can be found here. If available, investing in a 100W laser cutter is highly recommended for handling these materials effectively.

posts.name: ehochstein
posts.cooked:
Last year, I posted about our experience with a 100W Omtech laser cutter. We've been using it all season and it became our prototype bottleneck‚Äîour students loved it so much. Team 461 recently received a grant from Subaru Indiana Automotive (SIA) to purchase an Omtech MF2028-100 laser cutter. While I intended to write a detailed review, I haven't had time yet. Overall, we're very pleased with it. Our laser cutter exceeded preseason expectations.  

We set specific key requirements to ensure it met our needs.

posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked: We were going to try and increase our funding for SRPP this season but unfortunately, we‚Äôve already tapped out our budget for the WC Open Project. As a result, I‚Äôll need to adjust our allocations and shift more money to WCP next year.

posts.name: Harrison Drake
posts.cooked: We have access to a 155W Boss LS-3655 laser cutter at work, which handles SRPP without issues. Recently upgraded to a 2.5" lens, and the REV cut settings are spot-on. This machine is sizable but can still accommodate 23x47" stock sheets. Fully kitted, it cost approximately $18,000 in 2024 dollars. Highly recommended.

link_counts.title: LS-3655 CO2 Laser Cutter and Engraver - Boss Laser ‚Äì BossLaser

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked: We own a 100W 2x3 ThunderLaser and highly recommend it. If we were to purchase again, we would aim for higher wattage and size, such as a 150W 3x4 model. The extra power allows for thicker materials and faster cuts, while the larger size enables full-size projects like belly pans, robot covers, and larger sponsor panels. OMtech appears to be cost-effective with good reviews, though xTool's upcoming metal-cutting options require more information before we can recommend them. Their newer machines are notably more expensive than standard CO2 lasers.

posts.name: Jackie Gerstein
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôve got an Aeon Mira 9 and a 30W fiber galvo laser. I love both machines, but the Mira 9 is way out of your budget and the galvo won‚Äôt deliver what you need. We are looking for a laser with 120+ watts and a 4‚Äôx4‚Äô bed, ideally under $7k‚Äî$5k would be even better if possible. I‚Äôm not aware of any laser that meets all these specs. What features can you be flexible on, and which ones are non-negotiable?

Budgeting for ventilation is crucial too. If you can‚Äôt set up outdoor laser cutting, plan for a fume extractor and frequent filter changes, which will add significant costs. The primary materials you want to use are plywood (up to 1‚Äù thickness), polycarbonate in both 1/8‚Äù and 1/4‚Äù thickness, and aluminum for engraving. 

Using a laser for quick prototyping with plywood and bumper frames sounds like a smart approach. It allows the CNC router to focus on more complex tasks, like working with aluminum. That setup worked well for us‚Äîprototypes in cardboard and plywood were fast and saved time on the CNC for more detailed projects.

That said, maybe you don‚Äôt need a 4‚Äôx4‚Äô 120W laser for prototyping. Our team used a 24‚Äùx18‚Äù 60W laser and found it rarely limited our work. Most lasers in your budget are glass tube models requiring water cooling, so factor in a chiller if one isn‚Äôt included. RF tube lasers are more expensive upfront but offer longer lifespan and comparable performance without water cooling.

Some recommendations: Thunder Laser offers good value with reliable support, while Omtech provides the best bang for your buck, though at the cost of some quality control. Their 2028 100W model fits within your budget. Hao-Tian also has affordable fiber galvo lasers worth considering.

link_counts.title: Maker 150W CO2 Laser Cutter and Engraver with Autofocus ‚Äì OMTech Laser

posts.name: Dale
posts.cooked: We‚Äôve been quite happy with our Omtech 100w laser cutting 1/4‚Äù SSRP and plywood. Just be sure to align it when you uncrate it and run a test to determine the optimum height. Never felt like we needed more power.
